instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logic <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hello,

USB-C meter does not power on, board appears bone dry

<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips both produce 3.3V and no unusual heat under thermal camera

injecting 1-8.6V into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> produces no amperage

<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> Measurements:

1) 500mA -> Slowly decreasing (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>)
2) 100mV -> Stable

please help me I'm still new to this :D

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logic <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Please post accurate information.
How do you get 3V3 on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, if USB-C meter stays black?
Do you really get black (no indication) USB-C meter ("does not power on"), or is stuck in 5V?

Never inject voltage into a power rail, before checking for short first.

No idea how to interpret your measurments to <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logic <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Thank you for the welcome. it really does not power on, I was using a dc power supply connected to a usb-c end with 20V going into it, then I removed it and hooked up 1V to the g3H line and it draws insignificant amperage 0.007A

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logic <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Don't do again such tests without reason.

"Do you really get black (no indication) USB-C meter...?"
If yes, the charger detects a problem with VBUS, or CC1/2 lines.
Check diode mode to ground at all LDO rails of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
